newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: RESEARCH ALERT-Bavaria upside seen limited.
newsitem.headline: RESEARCH ALERT-Bavaria upside seen limited.

text.p: Brokerage Suvalor SA said it sees brewing giant Bavaria, Colombia's hottest stock, posting a 46.1 percent increase in net profits in 1997.
But Suvalor also said Bavaria's stock has limited upside potential after its impressive run-up so far this year.
"It's quite difficult to expect a significant valuation in the remainder of 1997," Suvalor said in a statement.
Among factors capping its gains, Bavaria management has fueled uncertainty by failing to elaborate on plans, announced at a shareholder meeting March 21, to split its stock in two, Suvalor said.
The planned split is designed to reflect a formal separation of Bavaria's beverage and investment portfolio operations.

The annoucement of the split was seen as positive at first, but Suvalor said, "The absence of further information about this is generating a certain amount of uncertainty about the concrete effects on current shareholders."
Bavaria's net profit rose 22.8 percent to 26.07 billion pesos in the first quarter compared to a year ago. Operating income jumped 28.3 percent to 17.78 billion pesos.
Suvalor said it saw Bavaria's operating income falling over the remainder of 1997, and predicted it would end the year down 2.6 percent from 1996.

Bavaria is the flagship of the Julio Mario Santo Domingo conglomerate. In the 52 weeks ended May 15, its stock price skyrocketed from a low of 3,350 pesos to a high of 8,800. The stock closed Monday at 8,050 pesos.
Suvalor, which belongs to the Sindicato Antioqueno industrial group, gave no specific reason for the anticipated drop in Bavaria's operating income.
